title: How to know if a verb is Ru or U in Japanese - Quora

response.answer_text: How to tell the difference between る-Verb and う-Verb when both have the suffix ending of「る」/ru/? Hint: “Observe what comes BEFORE the「る」/ru/ suffix ending.” If there is「ある」/a.ru/, 「うる」/u.ru/, and「おる」/o.ru/: They are (100%) guarantee to be categorized as う-Verb. Example 「分かる」/waka.ru/ (“to understand”) →「分かり」/waka.ri/ (“understanding”) 「降る」/fu.ru/ (“to precipitate”) →「降り」/fu.ri/ (“precipitating”) 「踊る」/odo.ru/ (“to dance”) →「踊り」/odo.ri/ (“dancing”) So, this is an う-Verb because there is a「ある」/a.ru/ in 「分かる」/waka.ru/,「うる」/u.ru/ in「降る」/fu.ru/, and「おる」/o.ru/ in「踊る」/odo.ru/. For「いる」/i.ru/ and「える」/e.ru/: Mostly (about 90%; to be accurate) is going to be る-Verb. HOWEVER, there ARE exceptions where it CAN be an う-Verb. 「起きる」/oki.ru/ (“to wake”) →「起きます」/oki.masu/ (“waking”) 「覚える」/oboe.ru/ (“to memorize”) →「覚えます」/oboe.masu/ (“memorizing”) EXCEPTIONAL Example 「帰る」/kae.ru/ (“to return”) →「かえり」/kae.ri/ (“returning”)「入る」/hai.ru/ (“to enter”) →「はいり」/hai.ri/ (“entering”)「切る」/ki.ru/ (“to cut”) →「きり」/ki.ri/ (“cutting”)「走る」/hashi.ru/ (“to run”) →「はしり」/hashi.ri/ (“running”)「知る」/shi.ru/ (“to know”) →「しり」/shi.ri/ (“knowing”)* These are ALL う-Verb, DESPITE they have「いる」and「える」. The best thing to do is guess. At least, out of 5 vowels, 3 out of 5 is guaranteed う-Verb which is not that bad. Hope this helps.
